Line 9: Line 9:
These special coins have a [[legal tender]] only in Finland, unlike the normal issues of the Finnish euro coins, which have a legal tender in every country of the Eurozone. This means that the commemorative coins made of gold and silver cannot be used as money in other countries. Furthermore, as their [[Precious metal#Bullion|bullion value]]<ref>Precious metals in bulk form are known as ''bullion'', and are traded on [[commodity market]]s. Bullion metals may be cast into [[ingot]]s, or minted into [[coin]]s. The defining attribute of bullion is that it is valued by its mass and purity rather than by a [[face value]] as [[money]].</ref> generally vastly exceeds their face value, these coins are not intended to be used as means of payment at allâalthough it remains possible. For this reason, they are usually named '''Collectors' coins'''.
These special coins have a [[legal tender]] only in Finland, unlike the normal issues of the Finnish euro coins, which have a legal tender in every country of the Eurozone. This means that the commemorative coins made of gold and silver cannot be used as money in other countries. Furthermore, as their [[Precious metal#Bullion|bullion value]]<ref>Precious metals in bulk form are known as ''bullion'', and are traded on [[commodity market]]s. Bullion metals may be cast into [[ingot]]s, or minted into [[coin]]s. The defining attribute of bullion is that it is valued by its mass and purity rather than by a [[face value]] as [[money]].</ref> generally vastly exceeds their face value, these coins are not intended to be used as means of payment at allâalthough it remains possible. For this reason, they are usually named '''Collectors' coins'''.
â
The coins usually [[Commemorative coin|commemorate]] the [[Anniversary|anniversaries]] of [[History|historical events]] or draw attention to [[current events]] of special importance. Finland mints four of these coins on average per year, in both gold and silver, with face value ranging from 5 to 100 euros.
+
The coins usually [[Commemorative coin|commemorate]] the [[Anniversary|anniversaries]] of [[History|historical events]] or draw attention to [[current events]] of special importance. Finland mints four of these coins on average per year, in both gold and silver, with face value ranging from 5 to 100 euros.
== Summary ==
== Summary ==
â
As of 2 October 2008, 26 variations of Finnish commemorative coins have been minted: three in 2002, four in 2003, three in 2004, four in 2005, five in 2006, four in 2007, four in 2008 and one in 2009 so far. These special high-value commemorative coins are not to be confused with [[â¬2 commemorative coins]], which are coins designated for circulation and do have legal tender status in all countries of the Eurozone.<ref>{{cite web | publisher=[[European Commission]] | url=http://ec.europa.eu/economy_finance/the_euro/notes_coins8787_en.htm | title=Different types of euro coins | accessdate=2008-06-24}}</ref>
+
As of 2 October 2008, 26 variations of Finnish commemorative coins have been minted: three in 2002, four in 2003, three in 2004, four in 2005, five in 2006, four in 2007, four in 2008 and one in 2009 so far. â
| colspan="5" align=left | [[Johan Vilhelm Snellman]] (12 May 1806-4 July 1881) was an influential Finnish philosopher, writer, journalist and statesman, who championed Finnish culture and developed the structures of the modern civic society. Apart from developing the national education system and the Finnish language, Snellman, in his capacity as Senator and head of the fiscal committee, also introduced a monetary reform that granted Finland a currency of its own, the Finnish markka, in 1865. For this achievement, there is a statue of J.V. Snellman in front of the [[Bank of Finland]] building in [[Helsinki]].
+
| colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| [[Johan Vilhelm Snellman]] (12 May 1806-4 July 1881) was an influential Finnish philosopher, writer, journalist and statesman, who championed Finnish culture and developed the structures of the modern civic society. Apart from developing the national education system and the Finnish language, Snellman, in his capacity as Senator and head of the fiscal committee, also introduced a monetary reform that granted Finland a currency of its own, the Finnish markka, in 1865. For this achievement, there is a statue of J.V. Snellman in front of the [[Bank of Finland]] building in [[Helsinki]].
The obverse depicts J.V. Snellman, It also depicts the logo of the [[Europa Coins|Europe Coins Programme]]. The reverse design features represent the dawn of Finnish culture.<ref name=JVS_RSM/>

| colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| This issue celebrates the [[Finnish parliamentary election, 1907|100th Anniversary of the Finnish parliamentary reform]] that brought universal and equal suffrage to Finland as the first country in Europe.
The obverse shows the silhouette of a woman's and a man's hands, and below the hands ballots being inserted in a ballot-box. The Finnish word ''eduskuntauudistus'' (parliamentary reform) can be seen in this side of the coin.
The obverse shows the silhouette of a woman's and a man's hands, and below the hands ballots being inserted in a ballot-box. The Finnish word ''eduskuntauudistus'' (parliamentary reform) can be seen in this side of the coin.

| colspan="5" align=left| On 15 November 1917, the [[Bolshevik]]s in Russia declared a general right of self-determination, including the right of complete secession, "for the People of Russia". On the same day the [[Parliament of Finland|Finnish Parliament]] issued the [[Finland's Declaration of Independence]], a declaration by which it assumed all powers of sovereignty in Finland. On 6 December 1917, the Parliament adopted the Declaration, which is why this day is the national holiday [[Finland Independence Day]]. The independence of Finland was recognized by the [[Government of the Soviet Union|Soviet government]] on 18 December and approved on 22 December of the same year.
+
| colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| On 15 November 1917, the [[Bolshevik]]s in Russia declared a general right of self-determination, including the right of complete secession, "for the People of Russia". On the same day the [[Parliament of Finland|Finnish Parliament]] issued the [[Finland's Declaration of Independence]], a declaration by which it assumed all powers of sovereignty in Finland. On 6 December 1917, the Parliament adopted the Declaration, which is why this day is the national holiday [[Finland Independence Day]]. The independence of Finland was recognized by the [[Government of the Soviet Union|Soviet government]] on 18 December and approved on 22 December of the same year.
â
This issue celebrates the 90th anniversary of independence in Finland. The [[Obverse and reverse|reverse]] shows [[petroglyph]] aesthetics, while the [[Obverse and reverse|obverse]] has a nine-oar boat with rowers as a symbol of a true Finnish trait: collaboration. The first [[Flag of Finland]], independent since late 1917, was a red and yellow lion flag. This coin was issued to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the birth of the important Finnish author [[Mika Waltari]] (1908â1979). Mika Waltari captivated Finnish readers as early as the 1920s; by the end of the 1940s, a worldwide readership confirmed his popularity. His best-known and most loved book was ''[[The Egyptian]]'', published in 1945. The events in the book take place in [[Egypt]] during the reigns of the pharaohs Akhenaten and Tutankhamun. Soon after publication, the book became a [[Publishers Weekly list of bestselling novels in the United States in the 1940s|best-seller in the US]], and historians praised Mika Waltari for his detailed scientific knowledge of [[Egyptology]].

| colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| This issue commemorates the 200th anniversary of the [[Finnish War]] and the Birth of Finnish Autonomy.
The Finnish War was fought between [[Sweden]] and [[Russia]] from February 1808 to September 1809, with Finnish guerrilla troops helping on the Swedish side. As a result of the Russian-won war, the eastern third of Sweden was established as the autonomous [[Grand Duchy of Finland]] within the [[Russian Empire]]. Other notable effects were the Swedish parliament's adoption of a new constitution (also called [[Swedish Act of Succession]]) and the establishment of the [[House of Bernadotte]], the new Swedish royal house, in 1818.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://rsmint.com/2008finlandandeuro100goldproofcoinfinnishwar.aspx | title=2008 Finland â¬100 Gold Proof "Finnish War" | publisher=The Royal Scandinavian Mint | accessdate=2008-11-18}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
The Finnish War was fought between [[Sweden]] and [[Russia]] from February 1808 to September 1809, with Finnish guerrilla troops helping on the Swedish side. As a result of the Russian-won war, the eastern third of Sweden was established as the autonomous [[Grand Duchy of Finland]] within the [[Russian Empire]]. Other notable effects were the Swedish parliament's adoption of a new constitution (also called [[Swedish Act of Succession]]) and the establishment of the [[House of Bernadotte]], the new Swedish royal house, in 1818.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://rsmint.com/2008finlandandeuro100goldproofcoinfinnishwar.aspx | title=2008 Finland â¬100 Gold Proof "Finnish War" | publisher=The Royal Scandinavian Mint | accessdate=2008-11-18}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>

The motif on the coin is the passage from Sweden to Russia.
